user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_unmount:
```c
int lfs_unmount(lfs_t *lfs) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount(%p)", (void*)lfs);

    err = lfs_unmount_(lfs);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_unmount:
static int lfs_unmount_(lfs_t *lfs) {
    return lfs_deinit(lfs);
}
...
static int lfs_deinit(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // free allocated memory
    if (!lfs->cfg->read_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->rcache.buffer);
    }

    if (!lfs->cfg->prog_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->pcache.buffer);
    }

    if (!lfs->cfg->lookahead_buffer) {
        lfs_free(lfs->lookahead.buffer);
    }

    return 0;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
LFS_TRACE("lfs_unmount(%p)", (void*)lfs);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: the code simply calls LFS_TRACE with a format string and a (void*) pointer. MISRA C:2023 Rule 21.17 targets use of <string.h> functions (memcpy, strcpy, strncpy, etc.) that can access beyond object bounds; the fragment does not call any of those functions. (However, a violation could occur if the LFS_TRACE implementation used a <string.h> function unsafely — e.g. copying the formatted message into a too-small buffer with strcpy/memcpy: char buf[8]; strcpy(buf, "lfs_unmount(%p)"); — which would violate Rule 21.17.)
